Answer: (PLEASE READ THE ENTIRE ANSWER.)#1: Crazy fast Internet speeds.Today, we’re hitting an Internet speed of 1GBPS for the average (1st World) consumer.But as time goes, we’re sure to become quicker, faster, and more efficient as we keep inventing.Although speeds much above 1GBPS are possible today too, they are yet to come to the average person.Some guy will probably pop up in the next year or so that’ll make it happen.#2: Artificial Intelligence.Would this list be complete if I didn’t include it?I can say without contest, that AI is, by far the most advanced and powerful technology to be created(PLEASE READ THE ENTIRE ANSWER.)#1: Crazy fast Internet speeds.Today, we’re hitting an Internet speed of 1GBPS for the average (1st World) consumer.But as time goes, we’re sure to become quicker, faster, and more efficient as we keep inventing.Although speeds much above 1GBPS are possible today too, they are yet to come to the average person.Some guy will probably pop up in the next year or so that’ll make it happen.#2: Artificial Intelligence.Would this list be complete if I didn’t include it?I can say without contest, that AI is, by far the most advanced and powerful technology to be created in recent years.More than that, it’s developing so fast! With so many people, so many companies into the same thing, our lives will literally be crammed full of it.We’ve seen some examples of AI already—Siri, Cortana, Alexa. You name it, we’ve got it.#3: VR.Unlike other technologies, VR can neverIt will simply be a compliment, an enjoyment, a tool. But that doesn’t mean it won’t be widespread.One, VR can be used to capture video, and play them back in such surreal reality, that real life can’t compare to it. (That’s an exaggeration.)Two, VR can be used to visualize models, charts, designs, and make dataThree, VR can be used to play games, and keep ourselves so immersed into a story, and action, that it can be entertaining. No doubt video-game stores and malls will be full of sections dedicated only to VR gameplay. More than that, companies will be created that specialize in VR games, which will mean even moreIn the end, these are the three MAIN things I can see in the future, just right there, in front of us.ARMAAN AGRAWAL

question: https://www.quora.com/What-technologies-will-be-in-our-everyday-life-in-the-next-5-years

Answer: A statement from an Amazon delivery boy changed my perspective.Message flashed about the delivery of my package and I waited eagerly for the doorbell to ring.Anil(delivery boy) called me and estimated the arrival time. After a while I heard the doorbell and dashed towards the door where Anil handed me the package and I paid.Now comes the interesting part.The amount was 3699 ₹ to which I gave him 3700 ₹. He counted it twice and nodded as a gesture of approval.I was about to go inside when he interrupted me and said -Sir, aap apne chutte bhul gae.(Sir, you forgot your change.)I was surprised becA statement from an Amazon delivery boy changed my perspective.Message flashed about the delivery of my package and I waited eagerly for the doorbell to ring.Anil(delivery boy) called me and estimated the arrival time. After a while I heard the doorbell and dashed towards the door where Anil handed me the package and I paid.Now comes the interesting part.The amount was 3699 ₹ to which I gave him 3700 ₹. He counted it twice and nodded as a gesture of approval.I was about to go inside when he interrupted me and said -Sir, aap apne chutte bhul gae.(Sir, you forgot your change.)I was surprised because -I smiled and said -Bhaiya, aap rakh lijiye.(Brother, you keep it.)I'm quoting verbatim what Anil said -Sir 1 ₹ h to kya hua, kisi ne iske liye mehnat to ki h na. Aap kisi aise ko de dena jisko iski zarurat ho.(Sir, so what if it's just a penny, someone has worked hard for it. Give it to someone who is in need.)I was astounded after listening that. All I could do was hug him as he refused my offer for water.People like Anil work so damn hard just for 15,000 ₹ (maximum) delivering more than 60 packages a day with very less incentives.Taking an average of 50 packages a day with an estimation of 2 ₹ as a tip, they could get 100 ₹ as a tip for the day.After a week or two I saw him delivering few packages in my campus. We talked and he told me he got a raise as he was most consistent in his work compared to others.What he taught me?What I learned from him ?

Answer: You stop existing.Your body decomposes.The people who loved you remember you for a while.Then, they, too, die, and people mostly forget about you.Your grandfather had two grandfathers. If you’re like most people, you will know very little, if anything at all, about those men. They are dead. The people who knew them are dead. That’s what will happen to you. That’s what will happen to me.Is it sad? Maybe. But I’ll be too dead to notice.

Today's society is heavily reliant on technology. It has both positive and negative effects on the world and has an impact on people's daily lives. We live in a time when technological advances are common.One area of technology that has had a significant impact on society is how it influences learning. It has made learning more interactive and collaborative, which allows people to better engage with the information they are learning andTechnology has an impact on how people communicate, learn, and think. It benefits society and influences how people interact with one another on a daily basis. Today's society is heavily reliant on technology. It has both positive and negative effects on the world and has an impact on people's daily lives. We live in a time when technological advances are common.One area of technology that has had a significant impact on society is how it influences learning. It has made learning more interactive and collaborative, which allows people to better engage with the information they are learning and having difficulty with.It also improves your access to resources. With the invention of the internet, we now have access to knowledge 24 hours a day, seven days a week, and you can find practically anything online. Furthermore, it makes it easy for pupils to complete their assignments. Students can take quizzes and exams more readily, and teachers can hold extremely effective online classes.Many new electronic communication methods have emerged as a result of technological advancements. For example, there are emails, social networking, the ability to facetime someone on the other side of the planet, and video conferencing, which allows you to hold conferences online.

Answer: No, it is not worth it, and the reasons have nothing to do with automation or the pandemic. The virus situation will play out over the next few months or years, the air transport situation will be altered, but there will still be pilots.The airliners of today are already highly automated. There is relatively little economic motivation to increase the level of automation. Many experts say that the right thing to do is to do more practice of manual, hand flying techniques. This means that when automation craps out, you have a feel for how to fly the plane. In emergency, (and failure of automatioNo, it is not worth it, and the reasons have nothing to do with automation or the pandemic. The virus situation will play out over the next few months or years, the air transport situation will be altered, but there will still be pilots.The airliners of today are already highly automated. There is relatively little economic motivation to increase the level of automation. Many experts say that the right thing to do is to do more practice of manual, hand flying techniques. This means that when automation craps out, you have a feel for how to fly the plane. In emergency, (and failure of automation in a modern jet is a true emergency) you want to revert to something you are very familiar and comfortable with. Not something strange or rarely practiced.There are only a very few people for whom it makes sense to pursue pilot career. These people are true addicts, they will never be happy unless they are pilots. They might be someone who could never afford to fly unless someone subsidized their effort (military) or paid them (flight instructor?).If you want to be a pilot, you better be willing to put every other thing secondary. You better be willing to move. You better be willing to get up at any time of the day or night, go accumulate some hours. You better be willing to handle long periods of no income (like, during a pandemic or 9/11 terrorist crisis). You better be willing to endure poverty, chastity, and obedience. OK, maybe not so much chastity… Of course, I personally have always been faithful, but the joke around the ready room is that if your first wife was not a flight attendant, your second one will be….

Answer: It is, frankly, very unpredictable, and, unless you are a professional gambler, you better stay out of a pilot career.The threat of single-pilot operation, followed by pilotless operation, has been hanging over pilot careers for a long time but seemed distant.Coronavirus has brought in additional, more existential, threats.Boeing CEO David Calhoun’s prediction of a major U.S. airline’s demise has prompted complaints from some of the firm’s biggest customers. Mr. Calhoun told a television interviewer that a major U.S. airline would most likely go out of business by this fall.In an interview thaIt is, frankly, very unpredictable, and, unless you are a professional gambler, you better stay out of a pilot career.The threat of single-pilot operation, followed by pilotless operation, has been hanging over pilot careers for a long time but seemed distant.Coronavirus has brought in additional, more existential, threats.Boeing CEO David Calhoun’s prediction of a major U.S. airline’s demise has prompted complaints from some of the firm’s biggest customers. Mr. Calhoun told a television interviewer that a major U.S. airline would most likely go out of business by this fall.In an interview that aired on May 12 on NBC’s “Today” show, Mr. Calhoun said he expected demand for air travel to bounce back to 2019 levels in three to five years.Asked if he thought a major U.S. carrier might go out of business, Mr. Calhoun said: “Well, I don’t want to get too predictive on that subject, but yes, most likely. Something will happen when September comes around.”Nobody likes to hear the truth.American Airlines Group Inc. CEO Doug Parker called the Boeing chief this week to express surprise and disappointment.Mr. Calhoun’s comments weren’t well-received at United Airlines Holdings Inc. either. United also conveyed displeasure to Boeing over Mr. Calhoun’s remarks.Airlines are facing what executives have described as their greatest challenge in decades.Even with $25 billion in government aid aimed at paying employees through the summer and another $25 billion in federal loans, carriers say the situation remains dire.Major U.S. airlines, including American, United, Delta Air Lines Inc. and Southwest Airlines Co. have sought government assistance. U.S. passenger traffic is about 90% lower than a year ago as public officials ordered people to stay home to slow the spread of the virus.

There are 1000 far less radical changes which could have been made and they ended up “dead in the water”. OK dope and fabric and oxy-acetylene welding are still in the aircraft mechanic curriculum. First class medicals are good for six months. Mandatory retirement at 65. Vision must be corrected to 20–20. (For WHAT to see the magenta line? We are always operated IFR LOL) Most of the rules and certification standards we operate under go back to the airmail pilots flying CurtiNOT A CHANCE IN HELL. Here is why - the FAA which is essentially the defecto leader of ICAO is notoriously conservative. There are 1000 far less radical changes which could have been made and they ended up “dead in the water”. OK dope and fabric and oxy-acetylene welding are still in the aircraft mechanic curriculum. First class medicals are good for six months. Mandatory retirement at 65. Vision must be corrected to 20–20. (For WHAT to see the magenta line? We are always operated IFR LOL) Most of the rules and certification standards we operate under go back to the airmail pilots flying Curtis Jenny’s. Why because “the administrator or his designee” are infamously RISK AVERSE. Nevermind the “no pilots” thing, nobody is willing to do single pilot, or single pilot on aircraft with backup in ground control station at dispatch center. Nevermind getting rid of PILOTS, propose replacing flight attendants with a robotic vending machine that comes up and down the aisle??? See how THAT proposal goes. LOL Oh and before you say “but flight attendants arent just waitresses, I realize that. The vending machine can yell “BRACE BRACE BRACE” when ordered to go into emergency mode…. The FAA would spontaneously combust at the thought of getting rid of flight attendants. They wont even entertain reductions in the number legally required to accomaadate passenger load. (Its based on SEATS not seats FILLED! You could theoretically have sixteen flight attendants waiting on one or two passengers.) The FAA will NOT sign off on “no pilots” and if the FAA won’t do it nobody else can do it either because like it or not (suck this JAA/EASA) the US is the center of the aviation universe and the king of ICAO…. Not happening.

By the 1980s, all the hard stuff was done by computers.HONEST ASSESSMENTI’ll attract some negative comments for this next statement, but I stand by it.If any airline pilot hired since the 1980s had decided to never check weather, weight and balanI wish I’d known how boring and mind-numbing airline flying was.And that was in the 1970s when it actually took a lot of work and planning by the pilots. By the 1980s, all the hard stuff was done by computers.HONEST ASSESSMENTI’ll attract some negative comments for this next statement, but I stand by it.If any airline pilot hired since the 1980s had decided to never check weather, weight and balance, Notices to Airmen, or the maintenance log, they could simply arrive at the airport, walk down the jetway and strap in, and if the gate agent brought the paperwork, they could go fly. If any factor was out of limits, the paperwork would never arrive in the cockpit.In reality, to keep from dying of boredom, pilots do check all that stuff, but it’s mostly out of tradition. But the truth is: If the agent hands them the paperwork, they’re going.“OLD MEN” WARNED METo become an airline pilot, I first became an Air Force pilot. But it was just to get my training and hours for an airline job.However, the Air Force and I liked each other very much, which is something I did not expect even in the slightest.Toward the end of my legal commitment, I was approached by my squadron commander, by my wing commander (and this was the wing commander of the 89th at Andrews AFB), and by the Chief of Staff personally. All off them encouraged me to stay and told me I’d be bored out of my mind as an airline pilot.Ah. But I was 29 years old and at that age, we are smarter than anyone older than us, right? So I left, only to find out that those old fossils—who were old men in the 40s, well, okay the Chief of Staff was an absolutely ancient 52—knew what they were talking about.LUCKY FOR MEI got lucky and my airline was one of the first to go out of business and so I never had to make the big decision to walk away. I only had to make the little decision t...

question: https://www.quora.com/What-technologies-will-be-in-our-everyday-life-in-the-next-5-years

Answer: Transfer learning in ML models.Humans are really good at generalizing. We only have to see a few dogs before we can recognize a dog when we see one.Machines are not. ML models require millions of examples before forming a reliable classifier, and that classifier is very specific to the data on which it was trained. If your training data doesn't include dogs with three legs, the model won't recognize them. A machine that plays Go is useless at checkers.Transfer learning is the ability to apply a model from one domain to a different one. It's hypothesized that the reason humans learn so quicklyTransfer learning in ML models.Humans are really good at generalizing. We only have to see a few dogs before we can recognize a dog when we see one.Machines are not. ML models require millions of examples before forming a reliable classifier, and that classifier is very specific to the data on which it was trained. If your training data doesn't include dogs with three legs, the model won't recognize them. A machine that plays Go is useless at checkers.Transfer learning is the ability to apply a model from one domain to a different one. It's hypothesized that the reason humans learn so quickly is that we are fitting new examples into our existing knowledge rather than forming entirely new categories. If we could teach machines to do the same, they would learn exponentially faster and apply that learning more effectively.Transfer learning is a very hot topic in AI research right now, so I expect major breakthroughs in the next few years. I think this may be sufficient to achieve artificial general intelligence, but even if not, it will dramatically extend the range of tasks that machines can accomplish.
